If $f$(-1) = 9 and $f'(x)$ $\geq$ 3 for -1 $\leq$ \emph{x} $\leq$ 2,
how small can $f$(2) possibly be?
sols:
We are being told that the instantaneous rate of change of the function
is at least of 3 on the interval {[}-1,2{]}, so the smallest possible
value of $f$(2) is the case where the function has the smallest rate of
change, that is a constant rate of change of 3 which means it is a
straight line (of slope 3).

And since we are starting at the point (-1,9) with a slope of 3 and a
run of 3 (from -1 to 2) we will end up with a rise of 9 and so the
minimal value of $f$(2) is 18.

Alternatively, you can use the MVT (Mean Value Theorem), which states
that if \emph{f(x)} is defined and continuous on the interval
\emph{{[}a,b{]}} and differentiable on \emph{(a,b)}, then there is at
least one number \emph{c} in the interval \emph{(a,b)} (that is \emph{a
\textless{} c \textless{} b}) such that

$f '(c) = \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}$

If we assume $f(x)$ is differentiable on \emph{(-1,2)} and
differentiable and continuous on the interval \emph{{[}-1,2{]}}, we can
use the MVT which gives:

$\frac{f(2)-f(-1)}{2-(-1)} = f'(c)$

For some value \emph{c} in the interval \emph{(-1,2)}. However, we know
that $f'(x) \geq 3$ for any value between -1 and 2, thus,
$f'(c) \geq 3$. Adding this, plugging in known values, and simplifying
gives:

$\frac{f(2) - 9}{3} \geq 3$

Solving for \emph{f(2)} we get $f(2) \geq 18$, thus the minimal value of
\emph{f(2)} is 18.
